author: sky.cactus
content: Then we wouldn't have a forcing function to regularly exercise the deployment system.

author: potuz
content: I truly don't understand this argument of the deployment system. Aren't the PR's that only delay the bomb absolutely trivial? What exactly it's being exercised by just making small changes and forcing people to update. Same for the merge, it seems that for anyone that wants to maintain a pow fork of Ethereum and disable the bomb it would require almost no infrastructure: just delay it for years and keep the current clients as they are now with minimal maintenance. The only objective impact that I can see of the bomb is that it forces ACD to agree on something regularly. This in itself seems to be a non trivial task and perhaps it's already enough to make it worth maintaining it

author: sky.cactus
content:
> Aren't the PR's that only delay the bomb absolutely trivial?
Yes, but making client changes is one of the easier parts to the deployment process.  üòÑ

author: djrtwo
content:
it requires coordination to perform a network upgrade to defuse the bomb 
also requires external coordination to get 3rd parties to upgrade their software to support the fork

it sounds trivial but is, in my estimation, actually a bit of a hard problem for those performing contentious forks

author: potuz
content: But most of the hash power is concentrated in a few decision making people, perhaps I'm being too naive, but my bet would be that if a pool cartel wants to fork it would be trivial for them to do it.

author: potuz
content: I like the bomb in that it forces ACD to have consensus, I just don't see the security aspect of it

author: djrtwo
content:
external coordination is also non-trivial

but yeah, coordination here isn't fundamentally *hard*

author: timbeiko
content:
The way I see it, coordinating around diffusing the bomb is the first and easiest step that a legitimate fork would have to take. Perhaps an analogous software development example is something like FizzBuzz: an easy interview question which helps weed out candidates who can't program simple logic. Hopefully, having this bomb adds enough of a barrier that any fork at least has a minimal amount of technical + coordination capabilities, reducing the risk of constant "scam forks". 

For Ethereum itself, it does act as a medium-strength forcing function to upgrade the network üòÖ
